bboxes.raw_text:
The second half of 1868 prop
erty taxes become delinquent
after SPIN. May 4. County Treas
urer John Foote warned. If
taxes are not paid by then, a ten
percent interest penalty be levied
on the unpaid balance.


Payment should be brought to
the Treasurer's Office, 1925 w.
Durango, by S PM, or mailed no
later than IL pm. May 4 at the
Phoenix main post office. Pay
ments bearing a postmark later
than May 4 "p.m." will be de-
clared delinquent. Mailing ad-
dress is County Treasurer, P.O.
Box 64l0, Phoenix, 85OO5. I


Receipts from payment first
half taxes including the attached
stub should be returned with the
second half PAYMENT.

The Maricopa County Council
for Retarded Children will spon-
sor an Interdenominational Va
cation Bible School for Retarded
Children. 1t will be held at the
First Methodist Church, Central
at Missouri, June 8 through July
8, Monday through Friday, from
$50 to $3.50 pm. The theme,
Goods World is aimed toward
giving these youth greater ap-
probation ofG od' love andGod's
world.


Retarded children from the
ages of 6 through l6 are invited
to participate in the program
which will include crafts, relig-
ious music, Bible stories, re-
freshments and games.


For further information on this
program or for registration
forms, write or telephone the
Maricopa County Council for Re-
tarded Children, $50 w. Indian
School Road, .277-7605.

Retarded Children
To Have Bible School

assisted by Evangelist Annie P.
Carroll.


Herman Hayes. blind gospel
singer and pianist, provides mu-
sic.

M. Young, Jr.. executive direc-
tor of the National Urban League
called upon federal, state and
local governmental groups to
channel their efforts in the war
against poverty through the inter-
racial League affiliates in IS
cities across the nation. He dis
closed that League branches are
in the process of being organized
in ii additional cities and an
nounced the establishment of reg
ional offices to serve the East,
mideast and midwest.


"The Urban League has the
existing machinery to do the
job" he told press conference
here. We are going to zero in
on the problems Of training and
retraining. dropouts. strengthen
Ing family life, motivation for
good citizenship. unemployment,
illiteracy, and despair" Young
said. "To delay this program is
to invite chaos and unrest


The Urban League director
painted a grim picture Of the
problems which confront Negroes
and urged white Americans to
reject the appeal of racists and
demagogues like Gov. George C.
Wallace. Young said.


Of 100000 out-of-school and
out-of-work young persons be-
tween 10 and 81 years Of age,
half are Negro.


Of every four Negro workers,
one is unemployed.


Of every four Negro families.
three have incomes of less than
$4,000 and 90 percent have less
than $1,000.


He said that the new League
regional offices would help speed
the formation of local branches
in cities threatened by racial
discord. "While the Urban
League applauds the dramatic
techniques which other civil
rights agencies have used to call
attention to the. plight Of Negroes.
we intend - with their approval
and consent to go forward in
al all-out effort to wipe out the
conditions which feed the dis
content of the demonstrators"


The National Urban League will
establish on May headquarters
in New York City to serve the
New England and Middle Atlantic
States: a headquarters in Akron,
o.. to serve a four-state mid
east area: and headquarters in
St. Louis, to serve the midwest.
Regional offices in Atlanta and
Los Angeles will be strengthened.


Branches Of the National Ur-
ban League are in various stages
Of organization in l. cities and
groups in a score Of other cities
have indicated their interest in
the League 8 work Of creating new
opportunities for Negroes. Or
ganizational efforts, he said, are
going forward in Syracuse and
Rochester. in New York: Lans-
ing and Battle Greek. in Michi-
gan: Peoria and Lake Bluff. in
Illinois: Hartford, Conn.,: Erie,
Pa: Colorado Springs, Colo.:
indianapolis. Ind: and Green's
boro, NC.


kkkkkkkkkkkkkkkkkkxkkkk%

Revival services are being
conducted nightly at Emmanuel
Church of God, l545 w. Buckeye
Rd.


Elder FELTON, King, pastor, is

Boosters Club has been organized Easake Park promote
community park
Adult we'll youth and sched
ule for the busy ahead.


Booster Club meetings will be held each Thursday $40 pm.
Square dancing smnasics cooking and crafts will be taught
Any adult interested should attend.


Clarence Jackson park director from eight
eighty the city parks and this
Eastlake Boosters include George Whitfield Shirley
Johnson A. Walton. E. Wilson and Beatrice Jackson.


Others Messrs John Weber, H. Boyer Jackson
Lance.

His Imperial ghness Nerd Azatch Asia Wossen Crown Prince
Ethiopia welcomed by Greek Royal Guards Evzones
his arrival the Athens Ethiopian Arlines scheduled
flight attend the funeral King Paul Greece The Eo
Prince Her Royal Hghness Princess Irene Of
Greece, who stands at his left.


Prince Nerd is the of Emperor Halle Selassie.

Grady Hughes, real estate
salesman, has resigned from
Webb, Williams and Berry. Inc.
real estate brokers and insurance
agency. 2Ol7 E. Broadway Rd.

full articles.headline:
TAXES DUE
ON MAY 4th
full articles.article:
The second half of 1868 prop
erty taxes become delinquent

percent interest penalty be levied

Payment should be brought to
the Treasurer's Office, 1925 w.
Durango, by S PM, or mailed no

Phoenix main post office. Pay
ments bearing a postmark later
than May 4 "p.m." will be de-
clared delinquent. Mailing ad-
dress is County Treasurer, P.O.
Box 64l0, Phoenix, 85OO5. I


Receipts from payment first
half taxes including the attached
stub should be returned with the
second half PAYMENT.
